issues.description: The problem statement contains an internal contradiction about the collection type used for Farm.animals. The UML diagram (earlier in the problem statement) shows animals: List<Animal> while the textual instructions in Part 3 explicitly require using a Set implemented with a HashSet to ensure uniqueness. Students will be unsure whether they must use a List or a Set and whether duplicates should be prevented by the data structure itself.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the specification consistent: either update the UML to show animals: Set<Animal> (preferable, since the text requires uniqueness) or change the textual instruction to require a List if duplicates are acceptable. To preserve the educational intent (uniqueness), change the UML and all mentions to use Set<Animal> and note HashSet initialization in the Farm constructor.

issues.description: The reference solution implements Farm.animals as a List (ArrayList) and initializes it as new ArrayList<>(), which contradicts the textual requirement in the problem statement to use a Set backed by a HashSet to ensure unique animals. This mismatch may confuse students when comparing the expected solution and the specification—especially because the problem text explicitly asks for uniqueness via a HashSet.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the solution to match the problem text by changing the animals field to a Set<Animal>, initializing it with new HashSet<>(), and adjusting any methods accordingly (e.g., getAnimals/setAnimals signatures). Alternatively, if the intended design is a List, update the problem text to remove the HashSet/Set requirement and make the UML and textual description consistent.
